titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to The Packer Collegiate Institute records 2014.019
titlestmt.author: Pratt Institute, School of Library and Information Science graduate students and John Zarrillo. Digital materials processed by Erica López in 2019.
titlestmt.sponsor: This collection was processed and described with funding from The Packer Collegiate Institute and the Leon Levy Foundation. The Packer Archive website, The Packer Collegiate Institute: A Story of Education in Brooklyn, was funded by the Leon Levy Foundation. Digitization of audiovisual material in this collection was made possible by the Metropolitan New York Library Council Digitization Grant Program.

physdesc.extent: in 566 boxes, one flat file drawer, and one object
in 53 video files; running time of available interviews: 16 hours, 37 minutes, and 20 seconds.

did.abstract: The Packer Collegiate Institute records contain administrative records, financial records, architectural records, Board of Trustees records, student and faculty records, publications, photographs, audiovisual media, event ephemera, and memorabilia, dating from circa 1780 to 2016.
did.physloc: The majority of the materials in this collection are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact cbhreference@bklynlibrary.org at least three weeks prior to research visit.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date (if known); The Packer Collegiate Institute records, 2014.019, Box and Folder number; Brooklyn Public Library, Center for Brooklyn History.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Gift of The Packer Collegiate Institute, 2014. Prior to acquisition by CBH, the collection was managed by Packer's Alumni Association and its Development Office.

processinfo.head: Processing Information note

The records were donated to Brooklyn Historical Society (BHS) in 2014. In June 2015, BHS archivist John Zarrillo, assisted by Stephanie Coy, prepared the collection for transfer from Packer Collegiate Institute to BHS. This process included the consolidation of the collection from 445 boxes to 388 boxes. The collection's arrangement and description remained largely unchanged, although adjustments were made in certain areas to aid researchers. The finding aid and container list was converted from a Word document to an EAD XML file and imported into Archivists' Toolkit in July 2015.

In September 2015, John Zarrillo commenced processing approximately 80 cubic feet of records that remained on-site at Packer. This work was completed with the assistance of Katie Bednark and Laurin Paradise. Subsequently the arrangement and description of the collection was completely revised by the BHS archivist in June 2016.

In January 2017, the Packer Collegiate Institute collection (ARC.130), which was comprised of accessions 1985.061 and 1987.016, was incorporated into the Packer Collegiate Institute records (2014.019) by John Zarrillo. These materials include assorted catalogs, publications, and other ephemera. The provenance of those files is as follows: Portions of accession 1985.061 were the gifts of Katharine B. Cronkhite, 1960; Mrs. Joseph Keppler, 1966; Katherine W. Sawford, date unknown; and the Packer Collegiate Institute, date unknown. Remaining materials from this accession were acquired sometime prior to 1985. Accession 1987.016 was the gift of Georgia Giddings, 1987.

The majority of audiovisual material in this collection was digitized during 2019-2020. Material that was not included in the scope of the digitization project included close duplicates, unidentified B-roll, and items that were determined to have degraded beyond the point of successful transfer.

Born-digital material in this collection was donated on two 3 1/2 inch floopy disks, thirteen CDs, and twenty-five DVDs. The disks were imaged using Bitcurator-2.0.14. No viruses or personally identifying information was identified during imaging. The finding aid was updated to reflect newly imaged material. In instances when other copies of the content had previously been digitized (largely from MiniDVs), these items were not updated. A small number of disks were not able to imaged successfully (IDs 2014_019_media_007, 2014_019_media_014c, 2014_019_media_017i, 2014_019_media_017j, 2014_019_media_021.

bioghist.head: Historical note
bioghist.p: The Packer Collegiate Institute was established as the Brooklyn Female Academy on Joralemon Street in the Brooklyn Heights neighborhood of Brooklyn in 1845. It was formed by a committee of local citizens who were interested in the education of young women. The school's first president was Dr. Alonzo Crittenden, who presided over a student body of 350 girls from 19 states.

The school burned down on New Years' Day, 1853, and reopened in 1854 with the assistance of a generous $65,000 gift—the largest donation to aid American secondary education at the time—from Mrs. Harriet Packer, widow of William Packer, and former trustee of the Brooklyn Female Academy. One condition of Packer's donation was her request for the dissolution of the Brooklyn Female Academy Corporation, which was to be replaced by what is today's Packer Collegiate Institute. Prominent Brooklyn architect Minard LaFever designed the Gothic Revival building, presently known as Founders Hall.

In 1883, after Crittenden's death, Truman Backus assumed the role of Packer's new president. As a result, religious studies ceased to be part of the curriculum. During this period, Packer rose to a position of national preeminence in female education. In 1887, the east wing, designed by Napoleon Le Brun, was built to house the gymnasium and science laboratories. In 1907, an Alumnae Hall was adjoined to the physical plant and the subway was constructed under Joralemon Street, which required the school to remove the observatory dome from the main building. Spanning the years 1908 to 1918, Edward Jasper Goodwin served as president and the students received letter grades for the first time.

John Denbigh succeeded Goodwin and served as president until 1938, overseeing the 1926 addition of the penthouse in Alumnae Hall. Denbigh presided over the establishment of Packer's Junior College in 1919. The school endured the financial impacts of the Great Depression, which resulted in teacher layoffs and salary cuts. In 1938 Paul Shafer became the fifth president of Packer and oversaw the Centennial celebration in 1945. During the 1950s, Packer's Junior College began awarding Associate Degrees and in 1957, Pratt Hall was added to Packer's growing complex of buildings. In 1968, President Shafer retired and Jack Skillman took over the post. In 1969, the school acquired nearby St. Ann's Church.

By 1972, the Institute experienced major changes, including the disbandment of the Junior College and the introduction of a co-ed student body. The elementary school was divided into Lower and Middle schools during this decade and Peter Esty became headmaster in 1982. Succeeding Esty was J. Geoffrey Pierson who served as the president of Packer from 1990 through 2004. Pierson oversaw the major renovation of the school's buildings and grounds, include the complete renovation of the St. Ann's Church building, which was was completed in 2003. Following Pierson's retirement, Bruce Dennis became the head of school in 2004.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The records are organized into twenty-four series:
Series 4: Circulars, catalogues, and curriculum guides
Series 7: Financial records and Annual Reports
Series 10: Presidents, Headmasters, and Heads of School
Series 12: Development Office, Fund Raising, and Alumni records
Series 18: Audio, film, and video recordings
Series 24: Upper School History Club COVID-19 oral histories

custodhist.head: Custodial History
custodhist.p: Many items in the collection were donated by alumni to The Packer Collegiate Institute prior to acquisition by Brooklyn Historical Society. The identity of these donors has been noted in the finding aid whenever possible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Packer Collegiate Institute records contain administrative records, financial records, architectural records, correspondence, student and faculty records, publications, photographs, audiovisual media, and memorabilia, dating from circa 1780 to 2016.

The records relate to the administrative and business activities of the Institute, including meeting minutes held between the Board of Trustees and other committees, annual reports from the President of Packer to the Board of Trustees, funding raising, and alumni affairs.

Student activities are well represented in the collection. Files relating to students include student publications, yearbooks, theatrical programs, scrapbooks, student notebooks, numerous photographs, and audiovisual recordings.
Overall, the records document the history of women's education in Brooklyn, New York, and the community's rich cultural heritage.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access note
accessrestrict.p: Student records and personnel files are closed to researchers for 100 years from their date of creation. All other files are open to researchers without restriction.
Born digital materials are available onsite at the Othmer Library. Requests to acess born digital materials must be made at least 2 days in advance by emailing cbhreference@bklynlibrary.org.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use note
userestrict.p: Copyright held by The Packer Collegiate Institute. All uses beyond fair use requires a licensing agreement as per Title 17 of the U.S. Copyright Law.
Photographs of individuals and records pertaining to individual students or staff cannot be reproduced for commercial purposes.

relatedmaterial.head: Related Archival Materials note
relatedmaterial.p: The following collections also hold material relating to The Packer Collegiate Institute:

School composition books and diaries collection (1977.348) - Contains school composition books and diaries dating from 1849 to 1901 and belonging to various Brooklyn residents, including Maggie E. Briggs (a student at The Packer Collegiate Institute).
Lillian F. Robbins certificate from the Regents of the University of the State of New York (1977.414) - Certificate issued to The Packer Collegiate Institute student in 1872.
Brooklyn schools collection (1985.054) - Includes records on over seventy Brooklyn schools, dating from 1828 to 2015.
Blackburne, Woodward, and Ottaway family papers (2013.006) - Includes the papers of Packer alumna Mary B. Woodward (1871-1943).

Henry Nagel papers (2015.004) - Includes items belong to Packer alumna Winifred Gladys Nagel Pitt, including Supplementary Reading for the Academic and Collegiate Schools booklet (1922), Class Day program (1931), the Annual Sermon to the Graduating Class (1931), clippings, photographs, and an address titled "Bender of the Twig" by school President Paul D. Schafer (1939).
Allen J. Kone collection of Brooklyn postcards (2016.014) - Contains The Packer Collegiate Institute postcards.
Jacques Cortelyou papers (ARC.025) - Includes a Report of the Treasurer of the Brooklyn Female Academy (later The Packer Collegiate Institute).

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: The majority of the materials in this collection are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact cbhreference@bklynlibrary.org at least three weeks prior to research visit.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains charters and by-laws of the Brooklyn Female Academy (BFA) and the Packer Collegiate Institute, dating from 1847 to 2004.

The act to incorporation and by-laws of the BFA are also included in bound volumes of the school's circulars, catalogues, and reports located in Series 4: Circulars, catalogues, and curriculum guides (boxes 509-510) and Sub-series 6.2: Administrative reports (box 507).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains records of the Board of Trustees of Packer Collegiate Institute, dating from 1844 to 2000. It is primarily composed of meeting minutes, which include information regarding admissions, finances, extracurricular issues, student and faculty life, alumni gifts and development, and issues pertaining to the operations and welfare of the school. The series also contains a small amount of correspondence.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains various student administrative records, dating from circa 1860 to 1979. These include reports of Scholarship and Promotion, academic transcripts, attendance and admission records, and Regents Examinations.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into six sub-series:
Sub-series 3.1: Reports of Scholarship and Promotion
Sub-series 3.2: Secondary and Junior College Transcripts
Sub-series 3.4: Transcripts and Report Cards (all grades)

did.unittitle: Sub-series 3.1: Reports of Scholarship and Promotion

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains records of scholarship and promotion (or academic transcripts) of Packer Collegiate Institute students, dating from circa 1860 to 1979.
It includes:
Permanent Record of Promotions for 1869 and 1884; Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship circa 1883-1898; Permanent Record: Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship 1899-1911, vol. I-VIII.
Two bound ledgers titled Permanent Record of Promotions, 1869 and 1884. Student transcripts including the year of promotion to each grade and graduation. Promotion dates circa 1860-1898.

Sixteen bound ledgers titled Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship, dated between 1883 and 1898. Student transcripts include student name, age, address, grade level and scholarship in various subjects. Arranged alphabetically by last name of student. Additional students are included in the index. Dates of admission, promotion, graduation or withdrawal are recorded as well as the school from which the student was admitted and the class to which he/she was assigned, and the college to which the student was admitted, if any.

Eight bound ledgers titled Permanent Record: Semi-Quarterly Reports of Scholarship, 1899-1911, vol. I-VIII. Student transcripts with student name, age, address, department and grade. Arranged alphabetically by last name. Dates of admission, promotion, graduation or withdrawal are recorded, as well as the school from which the student was admitted and the class to which assigned, and college to which student was admitted, if any.
Two bound ledgers and one folder documenting students entering college, dating from 1927-1979.

Sub-series 3.2: Secondary and Junior College Transcripts

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by surname. Loose photographs that were unidentifiable are filed at the beginning of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the transcripts from the Packer Collegiate Institute Secondary School and Junior College, dating from 1922 to 1967. The transcripts include some or all of the following information: Student grades, dates entered and left Packer, date of birth, home address, parent's name(s), standardized test scores, extra-curricular activities, religious affiliation, and photographs. While most of the transcripts indicate if they are from either the Secondary School or the Junior College, there are some that remain ambiguous. There are records that contain information from both the Secondary School and the Junior College, and occasionally even Elementary School. Some transcripts show both maiden and married name if the student's status changed while attending the school. In most cases, the record is filed by maiden name. However, there are a few records where the maiden name was crossed out and replaced by the married name, in which case it is filed by the married name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series is comprised of student academic records, which were documented from circa 1900 to 1960. Records include report cards, transcripts, teacher comments, parent/teacher/student/principal correspondence, student photographs, and various notes (religious background, date of birth, parents' names, academic standing).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by surname of individual students, followed by bulk files arranged alphabetically.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains student transcripts and report cards for Packer Collegiate Institute students of all grades, dating from circa 1880s-1966. Some of these files were likely removed from Sub-series 3.2: Secondary and Junior College Transcripts and/or Sub-series 3.3: Elementary Student Transcripts at some point in the past.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains the Regents Examinations of Packer Collegiate Institute, dating from 1874 to 1882 and 1910 to 1950. There are some gaps between June 1931 and 1938, and no records for 1949. Information regarding student's age, address and grades on examinations in academic courses are handwritten in the booklets. The examinations were administered by the principal and signed by the deputies of examination. It also includes one Regents Exam confirmation, dating from 1870.

did.unittitle: Series 4: Circulars, catalogues, and curriculum guides

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains Brooklyn Female Academy and Packer Collegiate Institute circulars, catalogues, curriculum guides, and supplements, dating from 1846 to 2007. The circulars and catalogues contain annual commencement exercises; lists of students and graduates, members of the board of trustees, faculty and staff; course of study; and historical notations. The later curriculum guides focus primarily on Packer's course of study. Of note is a pamphlet entitled "Packer and the War" that was produced circa 1943.
Curriculum guides for 1987 to 1989 are filed in Sub-series 12.4: Curriculum files.
Catalogues for the Packer's Junior College are filed in Sub-series 20.2: Subject files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged chronologically, with bound sets and supplements placed at the end of the series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains files relating to Packer Collegiate Institute and Brooklyn Female Academy faculty, dating from circa 1840s to 2007.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Sub-series includes the minutes of the Academic and Collegiate Teachers' Associations and other faculty organizations, dating from 1883 to the 1970s. The various faculty committee minutes provide insight into the inner-workings of Packer drawn from the perspectives of faculty members. The minutes include draft examination schedules and letters to the Teachers' Associations from students and staff. Additionally, the sub-series contains faculty manuals (1967-1982), directories (2002-2006), and assorted miscellaneous files.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains files on individual faculty members, as well as faculty events and clubs, which were collected by Packer's Development Office. The dates of the material range from circa 1840s to 2007. An incomplete finding aid that includes dates through 2006 for faculty members containing name, subject taught, and date of death can be found at the beginning of the sub-series.

Included in this series are correspondences between faculty members; the writings of faculty members; newspaper clippings; personal letters and obituaries. The majority of faculty files are composed of information questionnaires and/or the initial employment applications. Individual faculty files of particular interest are Caroline Chesebrough, a 19th century writer; Bruce Tulloch, former Director of the Upper school; Eleanor Bannister, class of 1875 and distinguished artist who painted many portraits of Packer notables; Alex Bernstein, son of Leonard Bernstein; and Stephen Koplowitz, professional dancer/choreographer and director of Packer's dance program from 1984 onward.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series consists mainly of handwritten drafts and typescripts of correspondence and manuscripts, along with a smaller quantity of poems and plays by Alice Van Vliet, who was a Latin teacher at Packer Collegiate Institute from 1901 to 1905. The bulk of material in this collection dates from 1924 to 1927, when Alice Van Vliet studied and received honors in Classical Moderations at Oxford University in England and toured around post-WWI Europe. Van Vliet documented her experiences in a travel journal and letters that she composed to a large group of friends back in America.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Alice Van Vliet was an American, born on January 11, 1874, and died at age 61 on September 6, 1935. The first available reference to Alice Van Vliet is from the Brooklyn Daily Eagle newspaper, which reported that in 1898 Van Vliet was a teacher at the Berkeley Institute (now the Berkeley Carroll School), an all-girls school started in 1886 in Brooklyn, New York. Following this, she was a Latin teacher at Packer Collegiate Institute from 1901 to 1905. Van Vliet is listed as a reader for the College Entrance Examination in 1906, where her title is given as "Director of Latin and Greek" at Packer, and she is credited with holding an A.B. from the University of Chicago, granted 1896. The last known teaching position that Van Vliet occupied was in 1926 and 1927 at the Katherine Branson School in Ross, California.

A book of Van Vliet's poetry entitled Poems was published in 1937, two years after her death. The dedication reads, "in memory of Alice Van Vliet, January 11, 1874 - September 6, 1935, from her friends, to her friends".

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is organized into two sub-groups:
Sub-group 5.3.2: Travel Log/Diary Entries, Correspondence and Drafts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains four poems, two plays, miscellaneous manuscripts, and a collection of handwritten copies of Ovid poems. They are all in good condition, though the handwritten material from the early part of the 20th century shows signs of brittleness and age, and can be difficult to read.

did.unittitle: Sub-sub-series 5.3.2: Travel Log/Diary Entries, Correspondence and Drafts

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series consists mainly of handwritten drafts and typescripts of correspondence. This includes drafts of letters written by Alice Van Vliet and letters she received while she studied Classical Moderations at Oxford University, England, and traveled throughout Europe during the post-WWI period, 1924-1927. They conclude with correspondence from her time as a teacher at the Katherine Branson School in Ross, California. The tone of these letters is chatty and conversational, revealing personal experiences and the thrill of traveling and studying Classical Moderations at Oxford —referred to as "Mods" in many of her letters and diaries. The material in this Series is in good condition; most are not brittle, though some are difficult to read. Several of the letters were composed while on trains or boats and later typed. Because many of these letters are drafts, the paper is sometimes thin, the handwriting informal, and Van Vliet would often write on both sides of the paper in ink, which would seep through to the other side, thus making the letters almost entirely illegible.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains assorted administrative committee meeting minutes and reports for Packer Collegiate Institue and the Brooklyn Female Academy, dating from 1846 to 1997.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into three sub-series:
Sub-series 6.1: Committee meeting minutes and reports

did.unittitle: Sub-series 6.1: Committee meeting minutes and reports

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains meeting minutes and reports of the Committee on Instruction, Philanthropic Committee, House Committee reports, the report of the Committee for the Study of Co-education, the report of the Visiting Committee of Packer Collegiate Institute, and other committees, dating from 1885 to 1974. The Committee on Instruction meeting minutes document school related issues concerning faculty salaries, tuition rates, and graduation requirements. The report of the Visiting Committee is a compilation of Packer's self-evaluation and presents what the committee considers to be Packer's accomplishments as well as recommendations for areas of improvements, i.e., new curtains, assembly room use, and curriculum expansion, among others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains financial records, annual reports, and the records of the Pension Fund Committee, dating from 1845 to 2014.
The 1847 Annual Report and Treasurer's Report of the Brooklyn Female Academy is filed with it's Act of Incorporation in Series 1: Charters and By-laws.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains Packer Collegiate Institute annual reports, dating from 1938 to 2014.

The reports include a variety of information in addition to financial matters, such as additions to the pre-existing curriculum and field trips intended to prepare students for the SAT exam (1950-1951), which was introduced in 1949 by the College Exam Board. A report from 1938-1968 includes information regarding male admissions, added courses, extracurricular activities, and the damages from the 1964 fire.
The series includes two annual reports of the Brooklyn Female Academy (1849 and 1850).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains assorted financial records, dating from 1845 to 1994. It contains fundraising and administrative budget materials, including ledgers for the Mrs. Packer Memorial Window Fund, 1906-1909; Treasurer's Reports, 1912-22; and the Administrative Budget, 1922-1934. It includes typewritten and bound minutes of Packer's Committee on Finance, 1951-1968; and an itemized valuation of the Institute's stock holdings as of February 2, 1955, which summarizes the division of the school's $938,761.00 market investment, the bulk of which was committed to government bonds, public utilities, and chemical stocks. Other materials include a cash ledger, 1892-1904; the ledger for the Memorial Window fund, 1905-1906; the Backus Memorial Fund account book, 1908-1909; a plea for funds letter signed collectively by the board of trustees, 1917; Packer alumni pledge cards, 1917; an Endowment fund ledger, 1917-1921; check stubs, 1926-1932; and Centennial Fund documents, 1945-1961. The series also contains student tuition bills, 1866-1916.
Related records can be found in Series 12: Development Office, Fund Raising, and Alumni records.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series is composed of material regarding the Emery Pension Fund, created by Mary M. Emery in memory of Adeline L. Jones in 1945 with a $50,000 gift in bonds to be used for the payment of pensions to retired teachers of Packer. Included is correspondence regarding wording and modification of the fund, and copies of resolutions passed the Board of Trustees. The series also contains correspondence and meeting minutes regarding pensions 1928-1943; Pension Committee meeting documents, 1912-1969; and a retirement plan proposal, 1940.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains an assortment of material relating to students at Packer Collegiate Institute and the Brooklyn Female Academy, dating from 1837 to 2016. It includes numerous student publications, student notebooks and scrapbooks, student handbooks, directories, diplomas, and an extensive collection of theater production files.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is organized into seven sub-series:
Sub-series 8.2: Student work, scrapbooks, and other files
Sub-series 8.4: Student Handbooks and Study Guides

arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title, then chronologically. The word "Packer" is ignored for arrangement purposes.

Issues of The Literary Novice from the Brooklyn Heights Seminary are dated May 19, October 6, October 30, November 3, November 17, and December 15, 1854. These issues were sent to Mrs. Harold Quantin at Packer in 1943.

Packer Current Items was first published in 1909 – a copy of vol. 1, issue 1 is included in this series. The publication continued into the twenty-first century, marking it as the longest-running student publication at Packer. Date, volume and issue numbers are sometimes inconsistent. A few issues are missing (see container list for details). Also included in this series is correspondence from various alumni regarding the 50th anniversary issue of Packer Current Items, which was celebrated in 1959.

Sub-series 8.2: Student work, scrapbooks, and other files

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains an assortment of material relating to Packer students, including school work, scrapbooks, autograph books, correspondence, class and club meeting minutes, artwork, and ephemera, dating from 1837 to 2009.
Some highlights include:

The scrapbook of Mrs. Paul D. Shafer (1940s-1950s), which primarily contains information and clippings about her husband (Packer president); Mrs. Harriet Pecket Cabbage's scrapbook, which contains updates on members of her class (1901), including correspondences and family information, including birth and death dates; the 1893 scrapbook of Louise Van Arden, which contains a letter from Florence Nightingale congratulating Van Arden on her graduation; Bernice Dhuy's chemistry, physics, and psychology compostions books (1903-1905); and student accounts of September 11, 2001.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by title. Miscellaneous files are arranged chronologically at the end of the sub-series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains material pertaining to Packer's theater productions, dating from 1859 to the 2000s. Student productions were split into senior and junior performances during the theater's later years. Most of the images, press coverage, and papers in the series collection address senior productions. The students staged a Christmas Pageant every year that included a theatrical reenactment of the Nativity. In addition, repertory and modern productions were performed in the early spring of each year. The stage sets were built and the performances directed by students with adult guidance. In 1979, Packer Theater celebrated its 125th Anniversary by hosting "Today & Yesterday." For publicity purposes, retrospective material was collected about past theater productions for the Packer "Pelican" yearbook. Contents relating to individual plays vary, ranging from photographs and news clippings to promotional material, playbills, scripts, personal notes, and stage budgets.
The sub-series also includes some items relating to the Alumnae Dramatic Association.

Additional programs can be found in Sub-series 12.4: Curriculum files. Additional photographs of theatrical productions are found in Sub-series 17.1: Packer Collegiate Institute photographs. Audiovisual recordings of theatrical performances can be found in Sub-series 18.5: Theatrical recordings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains the collected papers of two individual students, Susan Losee and Elizabeth Post Morrow.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The sub-series is organized into two sub-sub-series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-sub-series contains the student papers of Susan E. Losee (Nichols), dating from 1865 to 1869. Papers include written exams, essays, lecture notes and exercise books, including a handwriting practice book, and cover a wide range of subjects, including French history, mythology, Latin, astronomy, geography, physiology, grammar/spelling, etc. Also included is a personal scrapbook of classmates' written entries. Eight illustrated "Reward of Merit" cards, awarding student achievement, are included, along with a Certificate of Academic Scholarship issued by Packer for admission to the University of the State of New York, dated 1869.

bioghist.head: Biographical note
bioghist.p: Elizabeth Post Morrow (1896-1992), the daughter of James Howell Post (President of the National Sugar Refinery) and Louisa Henderson Wells, was a student at the Packer Collegiate Institute, graduating in 1916. Her mother was also a Packer Institute Alumna (class of 1880), as was her daughter Betsey (class of 1943). As a student, Elizabeth Post was active in Glee Club, school plays and debates. She also was active in the Student Settlement Association. She lived in Brooklyn Heights after graduation (Remsen Street), and from the evidence of programs in her papers; she continued to attend Packer functions in the decades following her graduation. She married Thomas Morrow in 1920 and was identified as a philanthropist in a newspaper clipping found in one of her hymnals. She was Vice President of the Associate Alumnae of the Packer Collegiate Institute (years unknown). In 1937 she was appointed to the Packer Collegiate Institute Board of Trustees as the representative of the Association of Alumni. In the same clipping mentioned above, it was noted that she was the 6th woman appointed to the board, and her role was to help bring Packer policies in line with other similar educational institutions. Some time in the 1920s Elizabeth and Thomas Morrow established a homestead in Brookhaven, Long Island, where the Morrow family had formerly lived. The Post-Morrow Homestead in Brookhaven has become the headquarters of the Post Morrow Foundation, which was established by Elizabeth and Thomas to help preserve the rural character of Brookhaven and its surrounding areas in Suffolk County. Well into the 1970s Mrs. Morrow continued to give regularly, and often generously, to Packer funds.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The sub-sub-series is organized into four sub-sub-sub-series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-sub-sub-series contains Packer memorabilia, dating from 1880 to 1818. It includes some material (commencement program and issues of The Packer Alumna), which predate Post's school career. These items possibly belonged to her mother, who also attended Packer. Alternatively, Post may have acquired these items during her tenure as an officer of the Associate Alumnae or on the Packer Board of Trustees.

The bulk of the files date from Elizabeth Post's school career and the years immediately following. These include school publications; a collection of programs of student plays, Glee Club performances, debates and school wide events (1909-1918); a 1913 exam; the script of "A Rose of Plymouth Town" with acting notes throughout for the role of Resolute Story, played by Elizabeth Post; programs of plays performed by the School Settlement Association; a handmade 1914 Packer calendar; and a Packer Anthem Book.

did.unittitle: Commencement Programs 1880 – 1887, and pre-1909 school items

physdesc.label: General Physical Description note
physdesc.extent: in one box and four folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Several hymnals seem to be Post Morrow's personal copies, with editions from various years. The hymnals list Charles Taylor Ives and Raymond Huntington Woodman as editors. Most are in fragile condition. Several contained printed or mimeographed lyric sheets. The hymnals sometimes contain ephemera, including painted place cards (including ones for "Mrs. Pratt," "Mrs. Morrow" and "Dr. Brockway"), a clipping announcing the appointment of Morrow to the Packer Board of Trustees, and the Annual Sermon to the graduating class of 1925.

did.unittitle: Hymnals (includes lyric sheets and sermon) (6 folders)

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-sub-sub-series include files of major events at Packer, or materials around a specific topic that were kept separate by Elizabeth Post Morrow in her original files. File 1 contains 75th anniversary materials (1928) including invitations, programs around various celebratory events, as well as a pamphlet history of Packer 1853-1928. File 2 has a few items related to a dinner in honor Dr. John H. Denbigh (1937). Dr. Denbigh retired that year as president of the Packer Collegiate Institute. File 3 contains clippings, invitation, and programs for the Edwin Jasper Memorial Lectures (1938-1937). Robert Moses was the speaker in 1939. These are fragile and need encapsulation. File 4 contains Centenary Celebration programs, invitations, lyric sheets and other related from 1945. File 5, Class of 1916 Material, contains items found in an envelope related to the class of 1916, including invitations to special graduation events in 1916, dance cards, and programs. This file also has notes and clippings related to reunions in 1937 and 1966.

did.unittitle: Dinner to Honor Dr. John H. Denbigh

physdesc.label: General Physical Description note
physdesc.extent: in one box and three folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The bulk dates of the material are 1937–1972. The files contain a mixture of materials generated by the Associate Alumnae of the Packer Collegiate Institute, Packer itself, and personal notes from the school administration or other alumna to Elizabeth Post Morrow. The majority of the records are fund raising letters, reports, brochures and event ephemera. Some of these materials are informative, especially letters and reports to the Associate Alumni written by Packer president John F. Skillman. Topics cover the financial troubles or well being of the school, enrollment concerns (1952), closing of the junior college (1971) and the decision to become a co-educational school (1972). There are a few hand written memos relating to Associate Alumnae business, mostly dating from late 1930s to the early 1950s. Other materials include invitations and programs of school events, reprints of speeches by Packer presidents, promotional brochures (some of these have photographs), newspaper clippings covering Packer news, announcements of changes in administration, and expansion of the school facility. Materials of particular interest are: a report card from 1930s reflecting concerns with appearance and deportment, a 1972 Coeducation Study Preliminary Report, a study on the junior college, and a 1969 letter from President on changes being considered to the school. There are several issues of the Packer Times from 1972–1973.

scopecontent.p: The series contains items related to school events (commencements, Class Days, anniversaries, etc.) and daily diaries which record events and other day-to-day matters at Packer, dating from 1846 to 2015.

Additional event programs can be found in Sub-series 11.1: Administrative files, Sub-series 12.4: Curriculum files, Sub-series 12.10: Alumni Questionnaires, and Sub-series 12.15: Alumni Association Geographic Chapters.
Programs for Packer theatrical performances are filed in Sub-series 8.3: Packer Theater.
Additional files relating to commencements are available in Sub-series 12.5: Graduation files.
Items relating to Alumni Events are filed in Sub-series 12.14: Alumni Events and Sub-series 12.15: Alumni Association Geographic Chapters.
Photographs of events can be found in Series 17: Photographs and audiovisual recording of events can be found in Series 18: Audio, film, and video recordings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series includes two significant sets of correspondence. The first is correspondence to/from Dr. Truman Jay Backus (1842-1908), President of the Faculty at Packer Collegiate Institute from September 1883 through March 1908. The range of topics covered in this correspondence to/from Dr. Truman Jay Backus (1842-1908) includes scholastic accommodations and referrals for students, scholarship recommendations, faculty accommodations, and recommendations for teacher applicants and administrative matters such as building maintenance and facilities.

The sub-series has been broken into four sub-sub-series that include: 1) Multiple Correspondences arranged alphabetically by name; 2) General Correspondence between teachers; 3) Chronological files; and 4) Biographical/Memorabilia of Truman J. Backus

Highlights from this sub-sub-series include correspondence with William C. Lawton which constitutes a full exchange between Lawton and Dr. Backus about a teaching position, including interesting professional negotiations. Mr. Lawton did not end up teaching at the school. Noteworthy are the teacher recommendations made to Backus by Miss Lucy M. Salmon, Associate Professor of History at Vassar.

Additional materials include a folder containing correspondence between Backus and members of the Board of Trustees including letters from Board member Seth Low (1850-1916), who was the Mayor of Brooklyn, the Mayor of New York City, and served as the President of Columbia University. It also includes a six-page letter from Mr. McKeen, board member, in opposition to recommendations to the board to increase tuition. Also of noted significance is the last folder in the sub-series: correspondences between parents and Dr. Backus (1882-1891). The topics covered in this set include parental concerns over scarlet fever, scholarships, and lunch dismissals.

Contains letters between Truman J. Backus and members of the teaching faculty. There is a letter written by Backus to the teaching staff asking for their opinions on the usage of the phrases "awfully bad" and "awfully pretty" (1900) and several responses from the teaching staff.

In addition, an eight-page letter from the Committee on Instruction (1899) regarding the possible reduction in teaching staff; a twenty page Report from Dr. Backus to the Committee on Instruction (1886) regarding curriculum; reports from Miss Susan K. Cook, teacher of "Mental and Moral Philosophy"; a report on individual teacher performance and recommendations about changes in assignments for teachers. This final report provides instructions on teaching etiquette accompanied by a 3 page statistical report.
Includes folders that span the years 1883-1894 with the exception of 1893.

Contained in this sub-sub-series are 1) Published items written by Dr. Backus and 2) Biographical material about Dr. Backus. There is a short pamphlet written by Dr. Backus entitled: "Various Phases of an Important Subject" pertaining to the education of Blacks in the South, published by American Missionary Association, 12 pages. This sub series also contains a memorial essay written about the school's founder, Harriet Packer by Dr. Backus, and describes the education of young women in Brooklyn, in addition to detailing the first meeting between Dr. Backus and Mrs. Packer.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains assorted materials from Packer Collegiate Institute's President Dr. Paul Shafer, 1938 – 1968.

The first group of materials consists of speeches delivered to students, faculty, parents and/or alumni by Dr. Shafer between 1930-1953. The speeches address WWII and its impact on education. Speeches following WWII are addressed to the PTA and focus on education within the home. Two examples of Shafer's writings appear in print outside of the Packer community: Forbes Magazine and Vital Speeches of the Day. A large formal document, with the signature and official seal of New York City's Mayor, Fiorello H. LaGuardia, and names Shafer a trustee of the Brooklyn Public Library. Shafer's 1967 announcement of his retirement is also included in the series by the Alumni Association. Materials are in good condition, although, Vital Speeches of the Day magazine's condition is deteriorating and should be handled with care.

The secound group of material consists of Dr. Shafer's office files. Arranged in rough chronological order for the academic years between 1960-1967. Folders include: Annual Report, Daily Program, Finances, School Organization and Administration and Teacher Reports. Items within this group detail Dr. Shafer's philosophy of education, his leadership style and his thoughts regarding topical issues pertaining to the school as a whole. The format of materials ranges from printed programs to handwritten notes on 4 x 7 colored note cards.

The Annual Report folders contain President Shafer's notes in preparation of his reports to the Board of Trustees. The Daily Program folders contain Dr. Shafer's notes for addresses to groups including the Board of Trustees, faculty, and students at the beginning of the each school year. Many notes are typed with handwritten edits while others are handwritten. There are printed programs for school events such as theater performances or the Christmas Carol Sing. There are minutes from meetings of the Board, and there are lists such as, "Colleges entered by graduates of the Academic School."

The Finance Reports are inconsistent between 1960 and 1968. The Treasurer of the Board of Trustees is responsible for delivering these reports detailing school expenses for events such as theater performances or the Spring Concert.

The School Administration and Organization folders contain items dealing with campus life and the President's responsibilities. Some items are related to the faculty such as a description of the school's Major Medical Insurance policy coverage and a list of new teachers, or instructions, such as "Procedures for Examinations." Some items detail student life, for example Permission Slip forms for a school dance or a directive regarding the lapsed enforcement of rules prohibiting girls from leaving school between the times of arrival and dismissal. Miscellaneous items include air raid drill instructions and a list of families with two or more children in the school.

The Teachers' Report folders are comprised of evaluations by faculty members, reports on the activities school clubs and reports from the dean and department heads. Among the materials are mimeographed examples of class assignments and exams.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is composed of files maintained by Packer''s Office of Public Relations. It include administrative files, press releases, photographs, clippings, scrapbooks, promotional items, and calendars, dating from 1848 to 2016.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains materials generated by and produced for the Office of Public Relations, dating from 1937 to the 1990s (primarily dating from the 1970s to the early 1990s). The items include interoffice memos among staff; correspondence between staff and advertisers, newspapers, educational directories, as well as correspondences between the Public Relations office and faculty, parents, and students. It also contains minutes from weekly meetings and school related conventions. Other materials includes: programs and academic schedules, handouts, scratch paper, bills, school histories, newsletters, and memos concerning school lectures and events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series consists of scrapbooks maintained by Packer staff, with items dating from 1848 to 1993. They contain newspaper clippings, photographs, letters, and programs pertaining to the students, faculty, alumni, and school events. Most newspaper clippings are taken from publications such as the Brooklyn Eagle. The sub-series holds some mounted newspaper clippings in addition to loose scrapbook pages.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains correspondence between scholarship fund donors, their agents and staff members of Packer Institute, as well as copies of donor wills, dating from the 1880s to the 1970s. The correspondence includes handwritten records of individual contributions to a variety of funds and scholarship programs, typed correspondence from donor attorneys, unofficial memos and cleared checks. In addition, overviews of various scholarships and miscellaneous financial records related to scholarships and funds are housed in the first file in the sub-series, "Packer Scholarship Fund, General".

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains materials relaingd to extracurricular activities of both students and alumni, dating from 1955 to 2007. The original folders were labeled "Curriculum Articles" and arranged according to specific programs, but also contained some unrelated material. Each folder contains clippings from internal and external publications, programs, flyers and registration forms relating to community service, culture, and events at the school. Of interest are some of the photographs, negatives and programs from Packer productions such as the "Dance Concert Programs" and other student productions.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains all of the Development Office files that pertain to Packer graduation ceremonies: graduation programs, speeches (including drafts and biographies with photographs of the speakers) in addition to paper work dealing with the administrative and organizational details of planning graduation ceremonies, i.e., ceremony memos, notes, correspondence with vendors and speakers, graduation reception invitations and even a couple graduation tassels. The years of coverage date as far back as 1916 but most records cover the 1970s, 1980s and 1990s.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains alumni questionnaires for the classes 1848 through 2002. Some files also contain alumni correspondence, news clippings, photographs, wills and testaments, and miscellaneous material (e.g. keepsakes albums, invitations, commencement programs, class materials, theater programs, and relating to alumni activities). Records regarding alumni funds, donations, bankbooks, correspondence relating to financial support of the institution are also included here. One unique item in this series is a birthday note written on birch bark by Mary Bond (class of 1886), dated 1901. Highlights include alumni information on notable students such as Mary White Ovington (1890), one of the early founders of what is now the NAACP; Elizabeth Woodbridge (1890), one of the first women to receive a PhD from Yale University; Ruth St. Denis (1898), pioneer modern dancer (nee Ruth Dennis); Lucy Burns (1899), suffragette; Janet Gale (1929), Pro-Choice Activist for Planned Parenthood; Nancy (Charlotte) Cushman (1933), Broadway actress; Sybil Hart Kooper (1945), Judge; Carin Vilonen, Miss Finlandia of 1966; Nancy Goliger (1968), Director of Adelphi University; and Maria Yatrakes (1999), Greek Olympic soccer player.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series documents various alterations, renovations, and new construction at Packer, dating from circa 1880s to 2006. It includes plans, specifications, blueprints, correspondence, and related files.
School floor plans dating from circa 1860 are located in a bound volume labeled "Compositions," which is included in Sub-series 8.1: Student publications (box 497).

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The series is organized into two sub-series:
Sub-series 14.1: Architectural drawings, plans, and administrative records

did.unittitle: Sub-series 14.1: Architectural drawings, plans, and administrative records

physdesc.extent: in five boxes and three oversize folders

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains architectural drawings, blueprints, floor plans, and projected renderings, dating from circa 1880s-2006.

It includes materials prepared by the Chapman, Evans, and Delehanty firm that document the extensive alterations and additions made to the Packer Collegiate Institute in 1957 and 1958. The various renderings and blueprints provide detailed information on Chapman's alterations. Large-scale floor plans of the entire campus are filed, as well as specific treatments of such areas as the dining room, gymnasium, sundeck, library, and greenroom.

The sub-series also includes drawings and blueprints created by various firms as proposals for the installation of the institute's steam heating system circa 1882. It is unclear which, if any of the firms, actually won the contract. Dated the same year is a correspondence from Otis Brothers & Company regarding the installation of an electric elevator. The company provided Packer with a blueprint for this elevator on June 5, 1891. The series also contains architectural blueprints and watercolors from 1944.

The plan books and specifications document a variety of alterations, building additions, and demolitions undertaken at Packer from the 1880s to the 1950s. The materials in the series affords researchers a vantage from which to better understand the architectural evolution of the campus at 170 Joralemon Street. Of special interest are: Architect William Tubby's specifications and instructions for the major alterations performed before World War I; James Gamble Rogers' materials and plans for the building's subsequent overhaul in 1940; the promotional materials describing proposed additions to mark Packer's centennial celebration in 1945; and intensive specifications describing the large-scale alterations performed in 1957 by Champan, Evans, and Delehanty.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains photographs in a wide variety of formats, including, but not limited to, black-and-white and color prints, negatives, glass lantern slides, carte-de-visites, 35 mm slides, digital images, and postcards. In addition to loose photographs, the series includes a number of photographic albums and scrapbooks, most of which were assembled by students. The images span the history of the school, from 1845 to circa 2010. Topically, the photographs document students (incuding individual portraits, class portraits, various school events, and activities), administrators and faculty, and Packer buildings.

Additional photographs can be found in Sub-series 8.3: Packer Theater, Sub-series 11.2: Press releases and photographs, Sub-series 12.4: Curriculum files, Sub-series 12.10: Alumni Questionnaires, and Sub-series 12.14: Alumni events.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains a substantial amount of photographs documenting life at Packer, dating from circa 1850 to circa 2010. It is primarily composed of prints, but also includes negatives (especially for photographs dating from the 1980s to 2000s), contact sheets, digital images, and other photographic mediums.

Thematically, the photographs cover various aspects of student life, including class work, arts, sports, class trips, special events, and extracurricular activities. It also documents the interior and exterior of Packer's building through the years.
The photographs were used for a variety of purposes, including the school's yearbook and various school publications.

Please note: many file descriptions include a five-digit, hyphenated number as part of the file description. These numbers are formatted XX-YYY, in which XX is a year indicator and YYY a sequential indicator. Thus, 98-002 indicates that the envelope is labeled as being from 1998, and is the second sequentially in its order, after 98-001 and before 98-003. These numbers were found on the envelopes in which the photographs were stored, and have been preserved to aid in the location of materials. However, they should be relied upon only with the understanding that not all photograph envelopes came with such a number, and thus the sequential ordering should be considered in no way absolute. In the instance that two photograph envelopes were found to possess the same numerical code, the two envelopes were designated within the file descriptions as variants (A) and (B) of the same five-digit code (ex: 98-002A and 98-002B).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains photographic albums, dating from 1864 to 1995. The albums primarily contain portraits of students, although the sub-series also include a 50th anniversary album and two albums relating to alumni.

Sub-series 17.3: Individual and Group Student photographic portraits

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains portraits of Packer students, dating from 1853 to 2000s. It includes both indvidual student portraits and class group photographs. The photographs come in a variety of formats, including cabinet cards, cartes-de-visite, prints, tintypes, and digital images. Of note is a daguerrotype of the first graduating class of Packer Collegiate Institute.

It includes the photographs donated by: Mrs. Clifford Keep from 1874, Mrs. Bertha Richardson from 1875, Mrs. Judith E Wallingford from 1876, Mrs. Lulu M. Snyder from 1889, and Irene M. Biertenshaw from 1912.
Additional student and class portraits are found in Sub-series 17.2: Photographic albums.

Sub-series 17.5: Glass Lantern Slides and Negatives

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains lantern slides and glass plate negatives, dating from circa 1885 to 1971, with the bulk of the series dating from the 1890s. The slides primarily document Packer's building, grounds, faculty, and students.

Series 18: Audio, film, and video recordings

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains audiovisual recordings in a variety of formats, including VHS cassettes, Betamax cassettes, Hi-8 cassettes, 8 mm cassettes, 3/4 inch tapes, 16 mm film reels, Mini DVs, DVDs, and audio cassettes. Subjects vary, and include events (especially graduation ceremonies), student theatrical performances, interviews with students and alumni, educational films, teacher seminars, and promotional videos. The tapes and reels date from 1933 to 2010.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is organized into five sub-series:
Sub-series 18.1: Packer Institute Day in the Life Production

did.unittitle: Sub-series 18.1: Packer Institute Day in the Life Production

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series consists of Packer Institute's Day in the Life school production materials. Arranged by material type, this sub-series covers a time span of 1995-1996, with a significant portion highlighting 1995. A Day in the Life series highlights interview questions and discussions asked to a select 17 students and staff at Packer Institute to show the impact of Packer on their lives as well as show how they impact life at Packer. Interviewees are asked about academics, extracurricular activities, the building and grounds, interactions with students and faculty, and every day occurrences at Packer.

The 17 students and faculty interviewed for this production were: Erin Burke, Simone Callendar, Garfield Davidson, Abigail Hooper, Peter Kelly, Vanessa Olivieri, Chartey Quanceo, Susan Roos, Alliyah Rosenthall, Cynthia Rothschild, Ken Rush, Barbara Seadon, Denise Schweid, Ben Shopsin, Sueta Srinivasen, Laura Zinck, and Erland Zygmuntowicz.

Materials and Condition: Media formats include beta video tapes, Sony digital audio tapes, Hi8 tapes, and 3/4 inch tapes. A majority of the media used for this production was recorded by Winton DuPont Films. There are also film scripts and interview questions which are both on camera and off, and production notes. Film scripts are in good condition and transcribed by Herman S. Jaffe.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains 16mm and Super 8 films, dating from 1931 to 1972. They include footage of Packer events, educational films, and one student film ("Exitus").

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock on metal reel with original cardboard container. Written in blue ink on container front. "Packer \ Class Day \ 1931." Written on container bottom. "DENTON." Written in pencil in upper-right corner of container back. "6044-1 \ Dupe-102." Written in pencil in upper left corner of container back. "K." Kodak Safety film, 16mm, 50' in length, B&W, silent. Very poor condition. Film curls and twists when unwound. Leader is dry and brittle. Original container in poor condition. Film stock is dented.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock on a metal reel. Kodak Safety film, 16mm, 50' in length, B&W, silent, edge code. Poor condition. Stock has an odor, twists and curls when it is unwound. Dry, brittle leader.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock in a metal reel with original cardboard Kodak container. Written in blue ink on front of container. "DANCE \ PACKER. SPRING, 1958." Large Roman numeral II scribbled onto front in blue/green crayon and crossed out with blue ink. Processing label from "Borough Hall Camera Shop" adhered to bottom of container. Reel flanges are tight/bent and prevent stock from easily unwinding. Imprinted into stock along edge. "PROCESSED BY KODAK MAY 58". "PROCESSED BY KODAK" printed on leader. Emulsion maintained bright, vivid colors. Kodak Safety film, 16 mm, color, 50' in length. Good condition. Dry and brittle leader. No scent to film.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock in metal reel. Safety film, color, 50' in length, silent. Edge code. Poor condition.Very loose on reel. Vinegar scent.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock on a metal reel. Stock features color footage of an outdoor school event. Kodachrome film, 16mm, 50' in length, color. Edge code.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock on a metal AFGA reel. Reel not unwound due to flaking emulsion. This is the only AFGA reel in the collection. 16mm, 50' in length.Very, very poor condition. Flaking emulsion. Dry, brittle leader.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock in metal reel. Kodak Safety film, 16 mm, 50' in length, B&W, silent. Edge code. Poor condition. Uneven wind. Bent stock at head. Torn sprocket holes at head. Film coils tightly when unwound.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock on a metal reel. Stock not unwound due to condition. Kodak Safety film, 16mm, 200', B&W, silent. Edge code. + Poor condition. Bent, dented, torn film stock. No leader. Torn sprocket holes. Loose wind. Slight vinegar scent.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock on metal reel found inside original metal canister. Yellow and blue label on can lid reads. "COLONIAL CHILDREN \ An Erpi Classroom Film \ ENCYCLOPEDIA BRITANNICA FILMS, INC. \ 1841 Broadway, New York 23, N.Y." Film not unwound due to condition. Kodak Safety film, 16mm, 400" in length, B&W, silent. Edge code. Poor condition.Very strong vinegar scent. Leader is brittle and warping. Reel flanges are loose and rusty. Stock is brittle and warped with torn sprocket holes.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock on metal reel in original metal canister with desiccated paint on can bottom. Three lines of illegible cursive writing on top can lid. Illegible print handwritten in pencil on reel flange. Stock was slightly unwound to identify film content. detached stock is a length of title frames ("From Osh Kosh to Anywhere") spliced to stock featuring a woman's face, spliced to animates frames. Animation on detached stock matches stock in reel. Kodak Safety film, 16mm, 200' in length, B&W, sound, + Poor condition. Tight wind. Broken sprocket holes. Stock is warping and brittle in places.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock in metal reel. Partially illegible pencil inscription on reel. Stock not unwound due to condition. Kodak Safety film, 16mm, 250' in length, B&W, silent. Edge code. + Poor condition. Stock and emulsion is scratched. Film has a slight odor. Stock is bent with torn sprocket holes. No leader, no can.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Film stock in metal reel. 3" x ½" rectangular discoloration on reel near flange edge; written on discoloration in pencil. "Packer Coll Inst". First hundred frames of film stock feature students entering and exiting Packer Collegiate's main entrance and students in a swimming pool. Kodak Safety film, 16mm, 400' in length, B&W, silent. Edge. Poor condition. Uneven wind with loose film stock. Stock is torn, bent, warped, and has torn sprocket holes. No can.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains audio recordings on cassettes and magnetic tapes, dating from 1946 to 1999. They include recordings of Packer events, educational conferences, and interviews with Packer alumni.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: The sub-series is organized into two sub-sub-series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-sub-series consists of audio recordings relating to Packer, primarily audio cassettes with a few magnetic tapes, dating from 1946 to 1999. Included in the collection are various graduations and ceremonies throughout the years at Packer. For example, the introduction ceremony for Geoffrey Pierson in 1990. In addition, there are tapes documenting important seminars: ATIS (Association of Teachers of Independent Schools), meetings as early as 1980, NAIS (National Association of Independent Schools), on the role of the arts in education, and yearly NAIS meetings. Copies of a 1977 performance of Gilbert and Sullivan's Ruddigore, and a teacher's clarinet concert are among the series performance section. Finally, the miscellaneous material includes one tape in which the connection to Packer is unclear – a radio show playing music from the 1950s.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Inventory with first, last, and maiden name of interviewee, and Packer class year / Accompanies cassette tape interviews of Packer alumnae and others.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains video recordings on VHS cassettes, DVDs, one Hi-8 cassette, and one Mini DV, dating from 1980s-2012. They include recordings on Packer events (especially graduations), promotional videos, educational seminars, and local news stories relating to Packer.
It includes a copy of the 1952 May Day celebration and commencement that has been transferred from film to VHS.

dao.xlink:title: Event: "Packer Collegiate Graduation, May 1952"

daodesc.p: Event: "Packer Collegiate Graduation, May 1952"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: May, 1952. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape. Good video/audio quality.

dao.xlink:title: Program: "Channel 7 News, on Packer Students," 1986

daodesc.p: Program: "Channel 7 News, on Packer Students," 1986

odd.head: General note
odd.p: VHS tape. Anchorman Bill Butello of Channel 7 news speaks with Packer students. Good audio/video quality.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: VHS tape. Japanese language expose on the state of public education following fiscal crisis in New York City. Quality of public education is contrasted with that of private schooling. Packer Institute is cited as an example – clips show classes in action. Good audio/video quality.

phystech.head: Physical Characteristics and Technical Requirements
phystech.p: Recording could not be digitized due to condition of original.

did.unittitle: "Show Close Bill 9/24/85. WABC-TV News. Bill Butel Ch7."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: September 24, 1985. 3/4 inch tape.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: May 07, 1987. RT. 12.00. VHS tape. Promotional video that makes a link between past and present at Packer. Interviews with current students and older graduates are illustrated with archival photo stills. Great audio/video quality.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: May 07, 1987. RT. 12.00. VHS tape. Dupe of VHS tape.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: April 02, 1988. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape. Consisting of unedited segments on student life at Packer. Shows children engaged in various classes, and footage of Packer architecture. Ends with clips of Brooklyn scenery. May be raw footage for another promotional video, or Japanese language "Broadcast NHK New York,". Folder 11. No identifying captions for speakers (includes administrators, faculty, and students). Great audio/video quality except for a brief period in which there is no sound.

dao.xlink:title: Program: "Schomburg Center & Packer Students, February 16, 1988"

daodesc.p: Program: "Schomburg Center & Packer Students, February 16, 1988"

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1988 February 16. VHS tape. Produced by WPIX Inc (NY). Tape is accompanied by letter dated March 24, 1988 from Warren Dean of WPIX Inc., addressed to MR. Hal Wicke, Director of Public Affairs at Packer. "Best Talk in Town" segment on Schomburg Center (and its role in preserving African American culture) is followed by an expose on student life at Packer. Narrator Warren Dean asks Packer students and teachers to identify Packer's special characteristics (in terms of teaching styles and learning environment). Video/audio quality is moderate. This is a 5th generation copy.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: February 26, 1988. VHS tape. Warren Dean narrates a segment entitled "Do private schools give college-bound students an advantage?" Packer, along with the UN International School, is cited as an example of independent schools. Richard Eyster, Packer Admissions Director is interviewed. Segment consists of clips also found in "2/16/88 Schomburg Ctr. & Packer Students," Folder 3. Good audio/video quality.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: June 15, 1988. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape. 1988 graduation ceremony comprising of preparations, speeches, choral performance, and diploma hand-out. There seems not to be a Commencement Speaker. Moderate audio/video quality, with a recording gap during the Class Speaker's speech.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1988. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape. 1998 Christmas Pageant celebrations at the Packer Chapel.

dao.xlink:title: Event: "Children Will Listen" Concert at Carnegie Hall

daodesc.p: Event: "Children Will Listen" Concert at Carnegie Hall

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Fundraiser, 1989 January 31. Possible location. Carnegie Hall. VHS tape. A collection of various performances by children and professional performers. Poor audio and video quality, roughly edited.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: 1989 June. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape. Unable to determine name of Commencement Speaker due to very poor to inaudible audio quality.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: June 1989. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape. Dupe of VHS tape in Folder 02, "1989 Graduation."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: VHS tape. Unreadable during time of survey, tape would not load properly.

did.unittitle: Unlabeled. VHS tape. World Wrestling Federation (WWF) wrestling program.

dao.xlink:title: The Day School - Grade 6 through Grade 12

daodesc.p: The Day School - Grade 6 through Grade 12

odd.head: General note
odd.p: VHS tape. Promotional video of various grade levels at Packer including the Day School, Upper School, and High School. Includes interviews with students, and clips of student engaged in various classes. Good audio/video quality.

did.unittitle: "Demo. John Gray Presentation. Sunday Today Program."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: RT. 13.00. Produced by John Gray Associates. TV special and interview with John Gray. Discussion regarding race, gender, and social class within the workplace. Good audio/video quality.

dao.xlink:title: Videotape 3 Garden Project. May Day Dance

daodesc.p: Videotape 3 Garden Project. May Day Dance

odd.head: General note
odd.p: April 28, ca 1990s. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape. Opening May Day activities and dances at Packer. Scenes of event clean up, finishing touches, and opening ceremonies. Good audio/video quality.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: June 14, 1990. RT. 25.23. VHS tape. Produced by Like Magic Entertainment Inc (NY). Puppet show geared at providing news/nature stories to young children. "Showtime Presents" mini feature highlights 4th Grade class at Packer having collected $15,000.00 in pennies for donation towards a rain forest preservation not-for-profit. Good audio/video quality.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: June 1990. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape.1990 graduation ceremony comprising of preparations, speeches, choral performance, and diploma hand-out. Commencement Speaker is Missouri Sherman. Good audio/video quality.

did.unittitle: "1990 Graduation Master. Filmed by Kathleen Hill."

odd.head: General note

odd.head: General note
odd.p: June 1991. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape. 1991 graduation ceremony comprising of preparations, speeches, choral performance, and diploma handout. Commencement Speaker is Ted Fisk.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: June 11, 1992. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape.1992 graduation ceremony comprising of preparations, speeches, choral performance, and diploma hand-out. Commencement Speaker is David Denken, former Brooklyn mayor. Key speaker is scholar Mr. Salisbury, expert in Chinese political history. Great audio/video quality except for a brief period in which there is no sound.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: December 17, 1992. Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. VHS tape. Class presentations on Hopi pueblo life. Topics include history, holidays, kachinas, clothing, communication, and politics.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: VHS tape. In and around the time of the Rio de Janeiro Earth Summit, Packer students head to Washington and Congress with an environmental message. Tape consists of news segments from various networks highlighting this visit. Great audio/video quality.

odd.head: General note
odd.p: Location. Packer Collegiate Institute. RT. 105.00.VHS tape. Students and teachers put on "The Peter & Carol Show," featuring students dressed up as (and making presentations on) prominent historical figures. Names on tape. Jud / Andy / Julia, Suzie / Rory, Allison / Cowell / Vanessa / Heather / Nora / JK. Biographical sketches on following. Leonardo da Vinci, Amelia Earhart, Rachel Carson, Roald Dahl, Florence Nightingale, Louis Armstrong, Sitting Bull, Olga Corbet, Laura Ingles Wilder, Nolan Ryan, Clara Barton.

odd.head: General note

Alan / Chase / Eliz / David / Chris / JP / Kristin / Zack / Charles. Biographical presentations on following. Malcolm X, Maria Tallchief, Abraham Lincoln, Jackie Robinson, Mark Twain, Bill Clinton, Louisa May Alcott, Thomas Edison, Jim Thorpe.

odd.head: General note

Edited montage of exterior and interior shots, students studying and at play. No identifying captions for speakers (includes administrators, faculty, and students). Great video/audio quality.

did.unittitle: "The Pythons 98/99 2LO. Interviews May Day Dance (2nd Graders?). In the classroom."

odd.head: General note
odd.p: VHS tape. This tape consists of a variety of clips. The opening segment entitled "Interviews with Brooklyn Heights Business January & February 1999" features student interviews with local business owners (includes baker, policeman, dentist, firefighter, etc.). Next, there is a brief feature on the Packer Maintenance Department. Then, there are excerpts from a May Day Dance from May 14, 1999. Lastly, there is unedited footage of Packer's elementary-level classrooms. Moderate video quality.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is organized into four sub-series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains instructional material used at Packer, dating from 1803 to 1964 (primarily 19th century). It includes glass lantern slides depicting assorted locations and attractions, textbooks, nature cards depicting various plants and animals, and photo cards which survey the history of western art.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series consists of glass lantern slides, dating from circa 1880s to the early 1900s. The lantern slides depict assorted locations and attractions taken at various times of the year in and around the United States (Niagara Falls; Yosemite Park; Old Faithful; Bee Hive Geyser, WY; a glacial fjord in Maine; a grain elevator in Illinois; a United State Navy warship; Luray Caverns, Virginia; Continental Divide and Grand Canyon, Colorado), Africa (DeBeers mine in South Africa; a caravan in Biskra, Algeria), Ireland (a peat bog in Killarney), and Australia (Tasmanian Forest).

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: No apparent order was found when processing. In order to aid researchers in locating slides of similar content, it is arranged alphabetically (by location if applicable) with multiple lantern slides of the same location filed next to one another.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series consists of textbooks that were used for instruction at Packer, dating from 1803 to 1964. The subjects are educational and include geography, history, and English studies. It includes volumes that were part of Brooklyn Female Academy's library.
