scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains instructional nature cards depicting plants and animals, including varieties of wild cats, birds, roses and others. The 104 cards are printed on approximately 3x4 inch cardstock in vibrant full watercolor, and are in near perfect condition. Images are clear, not damaged and are encapsulated in mylar in pairs. Each card is stamped with the date 1873. The cards are in order of their natural family and species. Those depicting animals give a perspective side view and include small diagrams of jaws and feet for identification. The plants are shown from a top/side view of the plant and shown in full bloom. All cards are mounted on black card stock with a descriptor on the back of the plant or animal pictured.

did.unittitle: Letter of Introduction. Quadrupeds-Wild Cats-Carnivores, 11 cards. Plants-Pink Family, 11 cards
Birds-Swimmers, 9 cards. Birds-Scratchers, 8 cards. Hollow Horn-Chewers (Cattle), 10 cards
Birds of Prey, 10 cards. Squirrel Family- Gnawers, 12 cards. Rose Family, 12 cards

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series contains 143 photo cards, which are photographs or prints mounted on heavy mat board. Images are mounted in both landscape and portrait orientation and vary in size. Mat board dimensions are predominately between 9x12 - 11x14 inches. Several prints are without mounting, all have been encapsulated. These photo cards were likely employed as visual aids in the teaching of a survey of western art and were often sold as thematic albums. The dates of use were likely during the last quarter of the 19th century through the early 1900s. The subjects of most of the images are Renaissance and Baroque art, including architecture (cathedrals, sculpture, plans, and elements), sculpture, paintings, and sacred decorative objects (reliquaries). Photographs were taken at the sites where their subject was created or resided at the time, which was primarily throughout northern Italy (Florence, Siena, Lucca, Pisa, and Venice). Many of the photographs include a caption or have a label fixed to mat board. A number of photo cards include maker's mark, the most prevalent being Alinari, the first and largest provider of these materials specific to the subject.

did.unittitle: 70 Photo cards depicting Western Art and Architecture

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains files relating to Packer's Junior College, which operated from 1919 to 1972. It includes evaluation reports and a set of subject files which address various aspects of the school, dating from 1932-1972.
Academic records of Packer College students are located in Sub-series 3.2: Secondary and Junior College Transcripts.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: The series is organized into two sub-series:

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains reports of the inspection of Packer's Junior College for the purpose of receiving accreditation by the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools (MSACS), dating from 1932 to 1970. It includes reports by the MSACS Commission of Institutions of Higher Education, as well as self evaluations by Packer. The reports detail observations and recommendations by Packer regarding its plans for the future and the fulfillment of its academic responsibilities. Topics include: setting, size, tradition, esprit de corps, purposes and objectives, programs, faculty, student services, library, admissions, alumni activities, and organization and administration.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series is composed of records relating to Packer's Junior College, dating from 1936 to 1972.

It contains a variety of material, including sample forms and letters used by the admissions department; President Skillman's letter announcing the closing of Packer College; and various studies and requests for information. Of particular note are files relating to the closing of the school.

Other items include: Guidelines for the acceptance and entrance of non-matriculated students, foreign student forms, foreign student files, including applications, forms and information. Disadvantaged student forms, American Council on Education Bill to Amend Higher Education Act of 1965, a College Work study Manual , the "Campus Disturbance Report" that includes a statement entitled "Violence and Disruption on the U.S. Campuses from 1968-1969" by Adam E. Bayer and Alexander W. Astin that was issued by the American Council on Education.

Other materials consist of a "Bill of Rights" for students by Patricia Curtis. The historical significance of these documents exists on both a personal and local level as visible signs of the disruption of campuses by students protesting the war in Vietnam and Civil Rights issues as well as the "tragic events at Kent State University which sharply intensified their feelings and sense of need." – taken from Rights of the Student, "Confidentiality of Student Records."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This sub-series contains a variety of artifacts and memorabilia relating to the Packer, dating from circa 1780 to 2004. It includes awards and commemorations presented to students, personal items belonging to former students, textiles, promotional items, and architectural memorabilia. Items of note include two wooden primers (presumably used in the 19th century), an assortment of historical flags and banners dating as far back as 1890, class pins and rings, school uniforms, plaques, and other honors. It also includes items which were used in exhibitions which were displayed at the school. Some materials were donated by Mrs. T. Stewart Harris in 2001 and Ms. Mary Jean Eckhardt Howard (class of 1946).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series includes plaques, awards, and other honors relating to Packer, dating from circa 1923 to 1999.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains items that were used in historical exhibitions at Packer, dating from 1839 to 1945. Materials include photographic prints, cabinet cards, drawings, newspaper clippings, manuscript letters, fliers, notices, official documents, invoices, receipts and stock certificates. They were used in as many as three exhibitions, one of which was almost certainly the centennial exhibit of 1945.

There are several items of note relating to the founding of the Brooklyn Female Academy (BFA) in this sub-series, including a notice of meeting in Brooklyn to plan establishment of BFA, the floor plans of the BFA building, and an invitation to the opening of the school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The sub-series contains assorted items relating to Packer, including promotional items, dating from circa 1780 century to 1995. Of note is a handcolored engraving entitled "The Inthronization of their Majesties also a View of the West End of the Choir of St. Peters in Westminster, and of the manner of Placing and Seating the Company in that Part of the Choir" (circa 1780), which was donated to the school by Sydney W. Davidson in 1957. Davidson was a Packer Trustee. It also includes two wooden primers that might have been used during the early years of the school.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains materials related to the Packer family (primarily Mrs. W.S. (Harriet L.) Packer, Miss Harriet P. Packer, and Mrs. W.S. (Mary K.) Packer Jr.), dating from circa 1850 to the 1990s.

Items relating to Mrs. W.S. (Harriet L.) Packer include her correspondences and a journal. The correspondence to and from Mrs. Packer covers a wide variety of topics. Mrs. Packer's journal details a trip to Europe taken between May and August of 1854. Also included in this series is a speech about Mrs. Packer by Mrs. Truman Jay Backus. The speech provides a description of Mrs. Packer's character, her devotion to women's education, and her vision of the Packer School.

The series includes material relating to the daughter of Mrs. W.S. Packer, Miss Harriet P. Packer, including a speech delivered at Packer's jubilee celebration and numerous letters regarding Miss Packer's death in 1909.

The series also contains the memoirs of Mrs. W.S. (Mary K.) Packer, Jr. The memoirs describe the impacts of the Civil War on the school, and family events such as the meeting with Mr. W.S. Packer Jr., her subsequent engagement and marriage to him. Historical information dealing with the aftermath of the Civil War: John Brown's raid, the nomination of Abraham Lincoln, the first Battle of Bull Run, Gettysburg, are the main subjects of individual chapters.

It also includes correspondence between Mrs. Packer and Mary discussing her attempt at attending college after a long period of absence due to poor health. The correspondence depicts a college bound curriculum.
The series also contains photographs (mostly reproductions) and portraits of members of the Packer family, including a daguerreotype of William Packer and images of the Packer mansion on Grace Court.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The series contains a variety of miscellaneous files that do not relate to the other series in the collection. It includes information on the Bates Collection and auction, inventories of silver and furnishings for the alumni lounge, and photographs of Brooklyn (unrelated to Packer). Of note is one file on a lawsuit between Packer and the University of the State of New York (1948).

odd.head: General
odd.p: In 1948 Packer Institute sued the University of the State of New York contesting the university's attempts to regulate the institute's activities. The judge ruled in favor of Packer, ruling that only the state legislature had the right of oversight of Packer Institute. Materials include court transcripts and the judge's official statement.

Series 24: Upper School History Club COVID-19 oral histories

physdesc.extent: in 53 video files; running time of available interviews: 16 hours, 37 minutes, and 20 seconds. All recordings are born-digital.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Arranged alphabetically by narrator's last name.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains thirty-two oral histories conducted during the COVID-19 pandemic by members of Packer's Upper School History Club with Packer staff, teachers, and students. The oral history interviews focus on narrators' experiences staying-at-home, or leaving Brooklyn, during the pandemic and how the pandemic impacted their lives. The first group of interviews were conducted from May 13, 2020 to June 1, 2020. The second group of interviews were conducted with twenty-one of the initial narrators six months after the first interviews from October 22, 2020 to December 3, 2020.
